Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Ultrafast Excited State Electron and Nuclear Coherences in Transition Metal Dimer Complexes and Their Roles in Photochemistry
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamic & Mechanism B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professors Lin X. Chen and Felix N. Castellano are developing the spectroscopy and chemistry necessary for the study of transition metal complexes featuring dimetallic cooperativity. These targeted molecules convert and accumulate energy from sunlight that can ultimately drive photocatalytic reactions for generating fuels. The knowledge obtained through these studies could be transformative for the chemical sciences and will enhance our ability to rationally design chemical materials/devices for catalysis, optoelectronics and energy sustainability. The research engages university graduate students to use advanced laser spectroscopy for characterization, incorporates state-of-the-art computational chemistry for quantum mechanical and molecular dynamics modeling, and utilizes advanced chemistry laboratory facilities for molecular synthesis, providing them with an expansive training ground for the development of multidisciplinary expertise. Such training is urgently needed for the next generation STEM workforce in order to explore the frontiers of chemical science and to ensure US global competitiveness at the frontiers of scientific knowledge.

The work studies quantum coherence in a series of di-metallic compounds, such as platinum, molybdenum, and tungsten dimer chromophores through systematic variation of structural factors. Mechanistic details enabling multiple-electron conversion processes are to be investigated through two-dimensional electronic spectroscopy and by the design of new molecular architectures. The research seeks an understanding of intrinsic electronic couplings between multiple metal centers in transition metal complexes and their influence on photochemical reactivity. Using ultrafast laser pulses as light sources, transient bond-making or bond-breaking processes will be induced between the two metal centers, which enable detailed studies on origins of their catalytic activities and fundamental reaction dynamics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
At the heart of chemistry lies bond-forming and bond-making processes occurring between atoms. This project precisely targets these phenomena by designing precise molecular architectures that enable bond-making processes that are triggered by the input of visible-light. Similarly, during relaxation processes following light activation, this transiently produced chemical bond breaks and the molecule returns to its original geometry. The research ultimately seeks an understanding of intrinsic electronic couplings between multiple metal centers in transition metal containing molecules and their influence on photochemical reactivity. Specifically, we designed multiple series of transition metal-based dimers where a metal-metal bond is formed following light excitation between two platinum(II) metal centers held close together in space. These molecules exhibit distance-dependent behavior in terms of their optical properties and were systematically varied through chemical synthesis by modulating the metal-metal distances through structural design of the ligand framework. The work at NC State largely focused on the design and synthesis of the molecules at the heart of the study. In collaboration with the Chen research group at Northwestern University, who measured the excited state pathways of these molecules using sophisticated ultrafast optical transient absorption and two-dimensional spectroscopy. We determined that the excited states of these molecules evolve with time after an ultrashort excitation laser pulse through different pathways depending on the electronic structures of the molecules, largely tuned by the metal-metal distances imposed by the ligand framework. When the distances were long, metal-metal interactions are weak and electronic transitions were localized on one-half of the molecular dimer; these transitions are best described as being strongly localized, either as ligand-centered or metal-to-ligand-charge-transfer in nature. By contrast, when the metal-metal distances were short, the electronic interactions between the two metal atoms become strong, and both sides of the dimer molecule now effectively communicate. Interestingly, in some of these excited states, the metal-metal distance significantly contracts resulting in a stronger interaction in their excited states. The sophisticated optical studies described above were used to elucidate the nature of the interactions from a quantum mechanical standpoint. We also examined the coherent nuclear (atomic) motions of the platinum-platinum stretching vibration in these excited state on the time scale of less than 10-12 seconds and found the change of the vibrational frequency for the platinum-platinum stretch increased due to the shortening of their metal-metal bonding distance in the excited state. Considering that there are several excited states that are energetically close with each other, the energetic fluctuations imposed through vibrational motion could potentially have significant consequences such as dictating or steering the outcome of photochemical processes such as excited state electron and energy transfer, which are photochemical processes at the heart of photosynthesis. The knowledge obtained through these studies have helped enhance our ability to rationally design chemical materials/devices for catalysis, optoelectronics and energy sustainability.   

This research engages University graduate students to use advanced laser spectroscopy for characterization, incorporates state-of-the-art computational chemistry for quantum mechanical and molecular dynamics modeling, and utilizes advanced chemistry laboratory facilities for molecular synthesis, providing them with an expansive training ground for the development of multidisciplinary expertise. Such training is important for the next generation STEM workforce in order to explore the frontiers of chemical science and to ensure US global competitiveness at the frontiers of scientific knowledge. The diverse and interdisciplinary project has primarily supported a female doctoral graduate researcher over the duration of the award along with one undergraduate student supported during the summer months at NC State. The graduate students at both NC State and Northwestern have learned to collaborate as a result of this project and each of them have served as co-authors on peer-reviewed manuscripts and have given presentations at numerous professional scientific meetings throughout the duration of the award.
